message: Volts. What motors are we using? http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__17265__Turnigy_nano-tech_6000mah_2S2P_65~130C_Hardcase_Lipo_Pack.html

I've already ordered the motors, which should be arriving in a week or so. They're rated for 2-3s cell (7-11V). Each motor should draw around 10A full load. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=6457, http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=5428
We need a xenon difluoride battery! Who's rich?

Also, at maximum current draw from the motors (40A) we're well within the capacity of the battery.  However, a good point is made in the comments about the impact of the packaging on the max discharge rate.
ALL of their money!!! (rubs hands together & cackles).... Oh wait... That's tax money, so it's kinda ours...
Excellent!  Now, let's work on a scheme by which we get them to give us some of their money.  Oh, wait.... ;)

@jasonaloy Cool.  With 10A motors and that battery, my back of the envelope calculation says we should get between 9 and 18 minutes flight time depending what current the motors require to just maintain altitude.  Also, we'll stay well within the battery's discharge parameters.
Haha.  @MickChagnet referring to the hobbyking link for the 6000mAh LiPo.  Am I horribly off in my estimate?
The calculation was a flight time of (in minutes):  (6 Ah) / (4 * x) * (60 min/hr)  where we assume the 4 motors together pull 4*x A from the battery, or x A each if they're pulling equally.
The numbers I gave are for x = 10A (9 min) and x = 5A (18 min)
Hmm.. You're accounting for the necessary voltage remaining, in order for the LiPo not to die?
Indeed.  Based on what I already know, I'd try to approach it in terms of power discharged, but I'm not sure what the horizontal axis is on a discharge curve anyway.

Nope, that doesn't fit on my envelope.  Also not sure what that voltage is, haven't looked up the discharge curve for that battery, and don't know for sure how to calculate a time estimate from that info anyway.
Yeah, little bit more than Ohm's Law going on there, methinks.
